q: What is acupuncture?
a: Acupuncture is a treatment derived from ancient Chinese medicine where fine needles are inserted at certain sites in the body for therapeutic or preventative purposes.

q: How does acupuncture work?
a: Acupuncture involves stimulating sensory nerves under the skin and in the muscles, resulting in the body producing natural substances, such as pain-relieving endorphins.

q: What conditions can acupuncture treat?
a: Acupuncture can be used to treat a wide range of health conditions, including chronic pain, headaches, migraines, prostatitis symptoms, and hiccups.

q: Is acupuncture available on the NHS?
a: Acupuncture is sometimes available on the NHS, but access is limited. Most acupuncture patients pay for private treatment.

q: How is acupuncture performed?
a: An initial acupuncture session involves an assessment of your general health, medical history, and a physical examination, followed by the insertion of acupuncture needles into specific places on the body.

q: Are the acupuncture needles painful?
a: You may feel a tingling or a dull ache when the needles are inserted, but you should not experience any significant pain. If you do, let your practitioner know straight away.

q: Is acupuncture safe?
a: When done by a qualified practitioner, acupuncture is generally very safe. Mild, short-term side effects such as pain, bleeding, bruising, drowsiness, feeling sick, or feeling dizzy are possible but rare serious side effects.

q: Is acupuncture regulated?
a: There is no statutory regulation of acupuncture in England. It is recommended to check if the acupuncture practitioner is either a regulated healthcare professional or a member of a national acupuncture organization.

q: Can acupuncture be performed during pregnancy?
a: It is generally safe to have acupuncture when you're pregnant, but you should inform your acupuncture practitioner to ensure certain acupuncture points are not used during pregnancy.

q: What are the potential side effects of acupuncture?
a: Some people may experience mild, short-term side effects such as pain, bleeding, bruising, drowsiness, feeling sick, or feeling dizzy. Serious side effects are very rare.

q: What is acupuncture?
a: Acupuncture is a treatment derived from ancient Chinese medicine where fine needles are inserted at certain sites in the body for therapeutic or preventative purposes.

q: How does acupuncture work in Western medicine?
a: Western medical acupuncture stimulates sensory nerves under the skin and in the muscles, resulting in the body producing natural substances such as pain-relieving endorphins.

q: What are the uses of acupuncture?
a: Acupuncture is used to treat chronic pain, chronic tension-type headaches, migraines, prostatitis symptoms, and hiccups. It is also used for joint and muscle pain, jaw pain, cancer symptoms, and side effects of cancer treatment.

q: Is acupuncture available on the NHS?
a: Acupuncture is sometimes available on the NHS, mostly from GP surgeries or physiotherapists, although access is limited. Most patients pay for private treatment.

q: How is acupuncture performed?
a: An initial session involves an assessment of your health, medical history, and a physical examination followed by the insertion of acupuncture needles. Courses of treatment involve several separate sessions.

q: What are the safety measures and regulations for acupuncture?
a: There is no statutory regulation of acupuncture in England. It is recommended to check if the acupuncture practitioner is a regulated healthcare professional or a member of a national acupuncture organization.

q: What are the possible side effects of acupuncture?
a: Mild side effects may include pain, bleeding, bruising, drowsiness, feeling sick, or feeling dizzy. Serious side effects are rare but can include a punctured lung or infection.

q: Can acupuncture be done during pregnancy?
a: Acupuncture is generally safe during pregnancy, but certain acupuncture points cannot be used safely. It is advisable to inform the acupuncture practitioner if you're pregnant.

q: What is the basis of traditional acupuncture?
a: Traditional acupuncture believes that when Qi, the life force, does not flow freely through the body, it can cause illness. Acupuncture is believed to restore the flow of Qi and restore health.

q: What does the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence recommend acupuncture for?
a: NICE recommends considering acupuncture as a treatment option for chronic pain, chronic tension-type headaches, migraines, prostatitis symptoms, and hiccups. Other treatments have unclear evidence.
